history.content: Ok... your point? Make them easier so that the value of a Cal CS degree is reduced?

children.subject: If they weren't hard, you wouldn't really learn much...

Unlike all those kids across the Bay, we actually care about academic rigor. If classes are easy, you're not learning much, which puts you at a disadvantage after you graduate. After all, a Berkeley CS degree is worth so much precisely because our curriculum is rigorous; if we dumbed it down, what would differentiate Berkeley (EE)CS from, say, SJSU?

Because the problems we face in the real world are hard; much harder than the ones presented in class. The problems we get in class are mostly the solved problems, but very hard nonetheless. To prepare you to tackle the hard problems you will face in the real world, you learn about the solutions to these problems that others have spent countless hours solving.  If classes were easy, when you are faced with a really hard problem, you wouldn't know how to start.

Also, what is wrong with having the top students stand out? For some reason, we are now living in a world where everyone expects to get A's and that simply doesn't make sense. Students who have a mastery of the material will be the top students in the class. 

And, I recognize that GPA isn't the best indicator of performance, but that's okay cause it's not really that important for finding a job.

+1 to real world problems are much harder. In 170, as hard as it is, you only learn very simplified versions of some real world problems. Take, for example, CS270, if you want to get a flavor of what the real world problems are like.

> For some reason, we are now living in a world where everyone expects to get A's and that simply doesn't make sense. Students who have a mastery of the material will be the top students in the class. 

This is true. I think people expect high grades because it's what they're used to from high school. I mean, I was livid when I got my first B+, even though it was an above-average grade for that course, according to Berkeleytime.

Speaking of which, I believe the curves shown on Berkeleytime are actually higher (more inflated) than they really are because they don't take P/NP students into account. (E.g., in non-prereq courses, the bottom fifth or so of the class might P/NP.) Someone correct me if I'm wrong.
No, I'm not saying they should be easier, I just want to know why they're so hard.

There are game theory studies all over the place about this, but in short, if everybody gets a 3.7+, that GPA is worthless. There's no option but to differentiate. If you had wanted a free 4.0, you picked the wrong school. We don't give handouts here.
@The Anon answer: I think whether the classes are hard or not has nothing to do with the degree (you can still get a CS degree with 2.5 GPA...) -- it's about the GPA.
I don't think most people worked from 7am - 1am in high school...
As a Cupertino student, I am puzzled when you tell me that people don't work 7am-1am

Lots of people have the impression that college is much harder than high school, simply because the average GPA is lower in college. But keep in mind that way less people care about getting a top notch gpa in college, because they are not planning to go to grad school after undergrad. Just think about it, how many of us now wake up at 7 am everyday and work work work till 1 am like in high school? The point is that we don't care about getting into good colleges, cause that has already happened. So people exaggerate this claim that college must be much much harder, but in reality people try less in college because the stress/stakes are lower.

history.content:
It seems like CS classes here are intentionally hard. In fact, the EECS grading guidelines recommend a 2.7 GPA average in each class.

I have a few explanations why.

- Avoid grade inflation (what's the point though?)

- Forces you to master the material

- The top students stand out

- Trains you to solve hard problems in the real world.
history.subject: Are Cal CS courses designed to be hard?
